text: Crabbe.
- - - VOIR DIRE EXAMINATION
Doctor, would you please introduce yourself to the jury?
speaker: MR. LAVIN

text: My name is Sachin Dheer.  I'm a diagnostic radiologist with training in orthopedic imaging.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Thank you, Dr. Dheer.  Would you please tell us what kind of medicine you practice?
speaker: MR. LAVIN

text: I'm a diagnostic radiologist, Board certified, and I have subspecialty or further fellowship training in orthopedic imaging.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What does the field of radiology entail?
speaker: MR. LAVIN

text: It's one of the specialities of medicine. It has to do with all of the imaging that's performed, whether it's x-rays, or ultrasound, or mammograms even.  My specialty is, as I said, orthopedic imaging.  Most of that is MRI, but we do other things as well, x-rays, and CAT scans.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.  And so would those be considered subspecialties?
speaker: MR. LAVIN

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And what is the importance of your subspecialty in orthopedic imaging?
speaker: MR. LAVIN

text: So the importance of it is that we have added training with regard to analyzing images and determining if there is a traumatic injury, what type of traumatic injury it is. We grade it the way an orthopedic surgeon would find it useful.  We specifically convey information that an orthopedic surgeon or other type of orthopedic physician would find useful.  And we are kind of used to using the same kind of terminology and coming up with what we call a mechanism of injury if we find a certain set of findings. So basically, we are kind of like the imaging counterpart of an orthopedic surgeon.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Can you tell us a little bit about your educational background?
speaker: MR. LAVIN

text: I went to college at The University Of Maryland.  After graduating, I moved to Philadelphia to come to medical school at The University Of Pennsylvania.  After graduating from medical school, I entered my first year of post-graduate training. We call that internship down at Georgetown University Hospital, also in Washington, D.C. After finishing that, I moved back to Philadelphia to start my radiology residency. That's a four-year program, which I did at Jefferson University Hospital, here downtown.  After finishing that, I elected to stay at Jefferson for an additional year of training.  That was the orthopedic imaging, which I finished in 2007. I have been in practice ever since.  Most recently, I worked at Jefferson as a faculty member, doing orthopedic imaging.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.  And Doctor, can you please describe your past and present teaching responsibilities?
speaker: MR. LAVIN

text: Sure.  Most of my teaching is to the residents and the fellows at Jefferson University Hospital.  I obviously teach them orthopedic imaging.  In addition to that, I give lectures around the country to other practicing radiologists on various topics in orthopedic imaging. I do teaching for emergency medicine residents, emergency medicine attendings, primarily in New Jersey, podiatry residents, who deal with the foot and ankle, orthopedic residents, who are, you know, orthopedic surgery trainings, both at the Rothman Institute here in Philadelphia and in New Jersey, and then various medical students from medical schools as well.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Dr. Dheer, are you Board certified?
speaker: MR. LAVIN

text: I am.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And can you explain to the jury what the significance of a Board certification is?
speaker: MR. LAVIN

text: Sure.  So to be Board certified, you essentially have to pass a series of examinations at different points in your training.  It starts all the way in medical school.  So you take a three-part examination at the various different stages of medical school in order to pass that.  You have to pass those in order to graduate from medical school. Then you take another series of three examinations over the course of your radiology residency to successfully complete that.  And then most recently, actually, we have instituted a re-certification process in radiology.  I'm actually part of the group that develops that test and puts questions to other radiologists in order to take that test. I have obviously taken it myself as well.  I have passed it.  So that's essentially what it is. The bottom line is it gives the public, the general public, a degree of confidence that, you know, someone that's Board certified basically meets a certain level of expertise and experience in their intended profession.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.  How long have you been Board certified?
speaker: MR. LAVIN

text: I completed my Board certification for the first time in 2006.  And then I have re-certified several times since then.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.  Do you belong to any professional societies?
speaker: MR. LAVIN

text: I do.  I'm pretty much a member of all of the major radiology societies, and then also the largest subspecialty society for orthopedic radiologists.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.  Have you ever been published?
speaker: MR. LAVIN

text: I have.  Being published, essentially, is you do research.  You add to the peer-review literature in the specialty that people learn from, and kind of we grow our knowledge base from that. In order to publish, obviously, you go through a process some call peer-review.  It's where your research methodology and your conclusions and your findings are all critiqued by your colleagues. So I have published several papers in the orthopedic radiology literature, in the orthopedic literature as well. And now in addition to publishing, I also critique other people's research, so I serve as an editor as well.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.  And I'm going to hand you now what has been previously marked for identification purposes as Dheer-1.  Can you identify that document, please?
speaker: MR. LAVIN

text: This is my CV.  It's actually not the most updated CV.  So for example, I used to be a clinical instructor.  Now, I'm an assistant professor at Jefferson.  But you know, so there is going to be more publications and such, but essentially, it's the same.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.  At this time I would like to move Dheer-1 into evidence.
speaker: MR. LAVIN

text: No objection.
speaker: MR. SPEZIALI

text: All right.  Your Honor, at this time I would like to offer Dr. Sachin Dheer as an expert in the field of radiology and orthopedic radiology.
speaker: MR. LAVIN

text: I have a few questions on Voir Dire.
speaker: MR. SPEZIALI

So even though I am sitting physically in New Jersey, I read studies from all across the Delaware Valley. Frankly, we have facilities all the way up in Collegeville, Pennsylvania, all the way through to, you know, New Jersey.

text: That's one of them.  So most days I'm actually physically in Marlton, New Jersey.  And the reason is because the Rothman Institute has a large -- kind of their New Jersey hub is in Marlton. It's a massive building.  We have an imaging center on the ground floor of their building.  Obviously, most of what we do is there imaging, because of the Rothman, you know, surgeons.  So I find myself there most days.

Reviewing films for patients as a treating physician, right?  How many days do you spend doing that work in Pennsylvania?

speaker: MR. SPEZIALI

speaker: MR. SPEZIALI

text: Sure.  So it's essentially consulting work that I'm asked to do.  So I get sent imaging studies.  I'm asked to determine if there is a traumatic injury of any kind.  If there is, I'm asked to describe it, characterize it, and determine if it could relate to an event that happened on a particular day.

speaker: MR. SPEZIALI

text: So in the situations where I actually know whether it's coming from a plaintiff attorney or a defense attorney, it's roughly 50/50.  And the reason I say "in the cases where I know" is because most of the time I actually don't know. And the reason for that is that most of the work that I get actually comes from these companies that basically, you know, put medical records together for their clients, whether, you know, whoever it may be.  And then they send it to me or they send it to whoever the appropriate expert might be in that particular matter. So in those cases, I don't know who their client is.  I don't know what side of the case they may be on.  It's makes no difference to me, because the way I do my reports is entirely the same. But in situations where I do know who it's coming from and I do have a general sense of, you know, whether it's a plaintiff attorney or defense attorney, it's roughly 50/50.  That being said, there are some firms that do both.  So you know, in cases where I know, it's roughly 50/50.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: That's all I have. No objections to the witness.
speaker: MR. SPEZIALI

text: All right.  Joe Lavin here again on behalf of the defendant, Talia Crabbe.
speaker: MR. LAVIN

Dr. Dheer, as you indicated, you reviewed three MRI films and authored a report regarding the plaintiff, Robert Miller, correct?

text: Yes.

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.  I want to focus your attention on the two MRIs of the right shoulder.  Can we pull those up?
speaker: MR. LAVIN

text: Sure.

text: All right.
speaker: MR. LAVIN

text: Going off record. Time is 4:16.
speaker: THE VIDEOGRAPHER

text: (Whereupon, the following discussion was held off the video record.)
Stand by.  We are back on record.  4:17.
speaker: THE VIDEOGRAPHER

text: All right.  Dr. Dheer, this is an MRI film, correct?
speaker: MR. LAVIN

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Now, can you explain for me what you can see on an MRI?
speaker: MR. LAVIN

text: Sure.  So MRI stands for magnetic resonance imaging.  It's one of the types of imaging that we use in medicine.  It's somewhat unique in that there is no radiation involved. But the other thing that is very unique about MRI is that it allows us to differentiate between different types of tissues in the body, whether it's bones or cartilage or muscle or tendon or, you know, nerves.  It allows us to differentiate all of those structures better than any other type of imaging. So it's been revolutionary, certainly in orthopedics, but in other specialities as well, because it allows you to visualize organs and other things as well. So within orthopedics, specifically, we're obviously concerned with the orthopedic-type structures, the bones and the cartilage and the muscles and so on and so forth.  So the first thing to realize is that any time we get any MRI of any body part, we get different types of imaging in different orientations. Okay.  So let me orient you first.  Imagine you are looking at Mr. Miller's right shoulder from the front.  So you are standing in front of Mr. Miller, okay, and you are kind of looking at his shoulder from the front.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.  I want to stop you there, Doctor.  Just for clarification purposes, what we are looking at now is a right shoulder MRI of the plaintiff, correct?
speaker: MR. LAVIN

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And that MRI is dated January 13th of 2015; correct?
speaker: MR. LAVIN

text: That is correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.  So we are here for an accident, which occurred on October 10th of 2015.  So this MRI that was done on January 13th of 2015 would have been before that date of accident, correct?
speaker: MR. LAVIN

text: Correct.  It was about nine months before the accident.  So even before we get in to what the findings are, right away we are aware that Mr. Miller had some complaints of his right shoulder, which sought him to seek out medical attention and MRI evaluation nine months before the accident.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So can you tell us what we are looking at in this MRI?
speaker: MR. LAVIN

text: Yes.  So imagine you are looking at Mr. Miller's shoulder from the front.  So this is actually going to be the surface of his shoulder. And this is kind of the rounding of the outside of his shoulder.  That's his skin surface.  This right -- this muscle right here is actually his deltoid muscle. So kind of the first muscle right under the skin.  There is actually two joints within the shoulder.  There's the glenohumeral joint, which is the ball-and-socket joint.  So this is the socket. This is the ball or the humeral head, which leads to the arm. And then as we kind of go back and forth from front to back and back to front, again, kind of taking slices through his shoulder as we are looking at it from the front.  This is the other joint, the AC joint, or the acromioclavicular joint. I think most people are familiar with that. If you kind of press down on your -- on the top of your shoulder right under your skin, you feel, you know, two hard bones.  That's your AC joint, okay? So most important structure in the shoulder to look at is the rotator cuff.  So the rotator cuff are a series of muscles and tendons, which basically give you the ability to elevate your arm. And so, this is the most important muscle of the rotator cuff, the supraspinatus muscle, this kind of gray structure right here.  It goes this way underneath the AC joint, which is out here, turns into the tendon.  So the muscle turns into the tendon and inserts on the outside of the arm or the humeral head, the ball of the ball-and-socket joint. So you can imagine every time the supraspinatus muscle and the other rotator cuff muscles contract, which is what muscles do, it pulls on this portion of the arm.  And your arm gets elevated.  So that's how the rotator cuff works to elevate your arm. So in this particular individual, there is no tear of the rotator cuff.  So you can see that there is a very nice continuous muscle leading to the tendon and inserting on the bone.  So that's good. There is something called tendinosis, which is essentially wear-and-tear or aging of that tendon.  And the reason we see this very commonly in virtually everybody that gets imaged kind of from their late 20s all through their adulthood is because all of the ligamentous and tendinous structures in the body have very poor blood supply. And so as a result, they start to undergo degeneration and aging.  We call that process tendinosis.  So this individual has tendinosis, which you would expect.  It's normal at this age.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So on this MRI film, which is dated January 13th of 2015, you do see tendinosis there?
speaker: MR. LAVIN

text: Oh, yeah, absolutely.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.  And that's a degenerative process?
speaker: MR. LAVIN

text: Yes.  It's aging of the tendon.  It's, you know, the tendon is made of collagen, which is connective tissue in our body.  And like I said, collagen has very poor blood supply. And so as we kind of age from our mid- to late-20s on through adulthood, it -- you know, all of the collagen in our body undergoes, you know, very slow, very progressive aging.  Specifically with regard to a tendon, it's called tendinosis.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.  Is there anything else that you are seeing in this right shoulder MRI?
speaker: MR. LAVIN

text: Yeah.  So, you know, the tendinosis is not really significant, because it's not necessarily causing problems or considered abnormal even, because everybody has it. What there is, is significant osteoarthritis.  Or, you know, most people just think of it as arthritis.  But it's essentially, you know, chronic ongoing kind of wear-and-tear of this ball-and-socket joint, the glenohumeral joint of the shoulder. So specifically, what are we seeing?  We are seeing that the cartilage has, over years and years, has kind of worn out to the point where it's gone. There is something called a labrum, which is essentially, again, a ring of cartilage that lines the socket of the ball-and-socket joint, kind of gives you added stability. It's what allows us to have a great 360-degree range of motion without dislocating our shoulder.  So the cartilage is worn away.  The labrum is -- is worn away to the point where it's completely resorbed and absent.  That's something that occurs over many, many years, and this kind of represents the end stage of that.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Can you point out for the jury where on the MRI you are seeing that so we can understand that?
speaker: MR. LAVIN

text: Yes.  Absolutely.  So this individual doesn't really have any significant labrum left. Where I would see it is over here at the bottom, and I would see it over here at the top. So you can see there is a little remnant of the labrum left at the top, but all along the lining of the shoulder here and at the bottom, it's completely resorbed.  It's absent. And so not only is it kind of worn out, but the body has resorbed it.  And that takes many, many years to happen.  And then because of that, there's arthritis of the shoulder.  So this is actually a big bone spur that's projecting off the bottom of the socket.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What is a bone spur?
speaker: MR. LAVIN

text: A bone spur is basically extra bone that forms at the margin of a joint.  It's really the body's response to the fact that there has been this ongoing several years of just, you know, wear-and- tear of the joint. So any time we see bone spurs -- and they occur everywhere in the body -- so arthritis in the knee looks the same, and arthritis in the shoulder looks the same, and arthritis in the back looks the same. It's all the same process.  The body responds the same way, you know, with this ongoing kind of wear-and-tear that occurs over many years progressively and you end up getting arthritis. This particular degree of arthritis in the shoulder is fairly advanced in that this is a very large bony spur.  And it takes a long time for these types of bony spurs to get this big.  So that's kind of how I can look at the shoulder. And I can kind of confidently tell you that there is no injury here that would, you know, have occurred.  All of this is something that has been kind of developing in a very, very slow progressive fashion over many, many years.  And what we are looking at is kind of an end-stage arthritis in this shoulder.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.  And so I just want to focus your attention that this MRI is dated January 13th of 2015, which would have been before the date of accident that we are here for today, October 10th of 2015, correct?
speaker: MR. LAVIN

text: Correct.  This was nine months before the accident.  And so basically, nine months before the accident, Mr. Miller was having some complaints of his right shoulder, which lead him to get this MRI. And I look at an MRI like this, and I say, "yeah, that makes total sense."  There is advanced osteoarthritis of this glenohumeral joint.
speaker: THE WITNESS

speaker: MR. LAVIN

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

speaker: MR. LAVIN

text: Sure.

text: Thank you.
speaker: MR. LAVIN

text: So when we look at the cervical spine, we recognize the fact that there are basically a series of stacked bones.  We call those the vertebrae, okay, that give us the rigidity and the stature in our necks.  All right.  And that's these squared-structures over here, okay. And then in between them are soft tissue structures, again, made up of collagen, right, that we were talking about earlier, connective tissue in the body.  And we call those the intervertebral discs or just the discs. And the reason we need those is because that gives us the ability to flex and twist and extend our spines and including our necks.  So we have the vertebrae and we have the intervertebral discs. Immediately behind that, we have this structure that comes out of the base of the brain and goes all the way down the spinal canal.  Okay. And is bathed in spinal fluid, which is this bright material over here.  That structure is a very important structure.  It's the spinal cord. Right.  It carries all the nerves and signals from the brain down through the spinal canal to the rest of our body.  And then on each side of the cervical spine towards the back are the facet joints.  Okay.  And these are like no different than all the other joints in the body.  Right. They basically form an articulation or a joint that holds the bones together and allows us to move.  So this is one side, the facet joints over here.  And then we're going to go off the other side of the neck.  And these are the facet joints over here.  So right away this individual has arthritis of the facet joints.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: How can you tell that?
speaker: MR. LAVIN

text: It's no different than the arthritis that we saw in the shoulder.  You can see the bony spurs here.  You can see the thickening of the joint capsules here. The reason I can say that this is fairly significant facet arthropathy is because, as the facet joints start to get arthritic and the bones, you know, kind of aren't held together the way they should because of the degenerative change, you start to get movement of one of the vertebra on another. And we are actually seeing a little bit of that over here.  And again, no different than we saw on the shoulder, the vertebrae respond to that by forming these bony spurs.  So not only do we see the arthritis in the facet joints, we see the bony spur formation in the vertebrae themselves. And then because there is this arthritis and this wear-and-tear of the spine, you start to see these age-related changes within the discs that we talked about as well.  So the first age-related change you see is the fact that these discs are dark. Now, unless you have, you know, a young person's spine to compare to, you don't realize this, but these discs are actually supposed to be much brighter, because on this type of MRI image, fluid is bright.  And normal discs, young, healthy discs contain a fair amount of fluid with the connective tissue. The fact that these discs are so dark tells you that they are what we call desiccated or dehydrated.  They've lost water content.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Now, would that happen related to a car accident?
speaker: MR. LAVIN

text: No.  That's actually the opposite of what you see in a traumatic injury.  When there is a traumatic injury of a disc or any other structure in the body, immediately the body has this intense, what we call, inflammatory reaction.  So it's the body's attempt to kind of like heal this off.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Would you be able to see that on the MRI?
speaker: MR. LAVIN

text: Definitely.  In fact, that's why people order MRIs.  And that's my job as an orthopedic radiologist to find these types of changes on the spine, not just age-related changes.  But we look for traumatic injuries, too.  And we characterize them and describe how severe they might be, and what structures are involved, and you know, all that.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Now, if you did see a traumatic image on the MRI, what would you be looking for?
speaker: MR. LAVIN

text: Okay.  So for example, a traumatic injury of the disc, the disc would be extremely bright, because there would be the immediate recruitment of inflammatory fluid and even blood we see sometimes, which we don't see that in any of these discs. These discs are extremely dark or desiccated.  They have lost water content. If we see a traumatic injury of any of the ligaments that kind of hold everything together.  So there is an anterior longitudinal ligament.  There's a posterior longitudinal ligament.  There is something called the interspinous ligament and then the nuchal and supraspinous ligament, which runs down the back of the spine here. Any time those are injured, we see fluid surrounding them.  If it's a severe injury of the ligament, we grade them as one, two, or three.  You know, we'll see, you know, frank, you know, free edges of the torn fibres of the ligament, you know, sitting in the middle of this fluid and blood.  We obviously don't see that here. If you see fractures, you'll see a fracture line, extending through the bone.  You may see a deformity of the bone.  Again, that will be accompanied by this intense fluid build-up.  So it literally shows up as extremely bright signal on the MRI.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.  So I just want to clarify for the jury that if there were a traumatic injury, there's several things that you would be able to see on this MRI, correct?
speaker: MR. LAVIN

text: Absolutely.  Absolutely.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And you are not seeing that on this MRI?
speaker: MR. LAVIN

text: No.  None of those findings are present. And then just to give you an idea of what it is to be an orthopedic radiologist, not only do we find those findings, not only do we grade those findings the way an orthopedic surgeon would, but then we put all the findings together, and we come up with a mechanism of injury. Like, you know, so when I do see traumatic injuries in the spine, I don't just say "this is torn," "that's fractured."  I say all of that.  And then I'll conclude by saying "this is consistent with a hyperflexion mechanism of injury" or a hyperextension or a torsion or axial loading.  Those are all, you know, different mechanisms that can result in different types of -- of injuries in the spine, so.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.  So I want to refer you back to your report of May 16th of 2019 that you had a chance to review this MRI of the cervical spine, dated February 23rd of 2016.  Did you form an impression based on this review?
speaker: MR. LAVIN

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Would you explain to us your impression and the reasoning behind your conclusions?
speaker: MR. LAVIN

text: Okay.  So my impression is that there's no traumatic injury of any kind.  Examples would include ligament and tendon tears, fractures, bruising, contusions, injuries of the spinal cord, the nerves.  All those things can be injured.  We don't see any of those. What I do see are very characteristic age-related changes in the spine, so arthritis of the facet joints, degenerative changes, and arthritic changes related to the discs and the vertebrae that surround the discs.  And that's, again, very characteristic.  Everybody develops them, depending on, you know, how old they are. And we see them very commonly.  And we obviously describe them.  So that is what I see here.  But I don't see any type of traumatic injury whatsoever.
speaker: THE WITNESS

speaker: MR. LAVIN

speaker: MR. LAVIN

And then, you know, a certain subset of those people unfortunately do sustain traumatic injuries on whatever body part that we are looking at.  So, you know, they can have a traumatic injury superimposed on.  Or another way to say it is aggravating a degenerative change. You would see that traumatic injury, that traumatic abnormality, whether it's the fluid build-up or the hemorrhage, or the tear of the ligament or a tendon on top of or in addition to or aggravating the age-related change that was already there. Just to be clear, that's not the case here. What we see in this case are solely age-related degenerative findings that were present well-before, you know, this accident. In fact, we have proven that in the right shoulder by comparing the MRI before and after the accident.  So you don't even have to believe me. You can just look at the images.  You know, they show you what it is. But yes, it is theoretically possible for somebody to sustain a traumatic injury on top of these age-related changes.  We see that all the time.  I see that all the time in my practice, because everybody has age-related changes and some people do have traumatic injuries.

text: And for the record, can you describe for the jury what is a herniation?
speaker: MR. SPEZIALI

text: So herniation actually has a specific medical definition.  It refers to the shape of an intervertebral disc in the spine.  So imagine a normal intervertebral disc has, you know, a donut shape to it roughly.  It's an oval. So a bulge, for example, is any outpouching of that disc that is more than 180 degrees.  So more than half of the entire circumference of the disc. A herniation is a more focal outpouching of that disc. Now, bulges and herniations, those are the definitions.  Those definitions have nothing to do with whether a bulge is traumatic or degenerative or a herniation is traumatic or degenerative.  All those definitions refer to is whether, you know, the shape of a disc is a bulge or a herniation.  That's it. The fact of the matter is that both bulges and herniations can be degenerative or traumatic. And if you just look at most of the people in the world, most bulges and herniations are, in fact, degenerative.  And the reason is because everybody develops age-related changes in their spine and relatively few people develop traumatic injuries of their spine, thankfully. But certainly bulges and herniations can be traumatic as well.  In this particular case, I just want to be very clear.  There were no traumatic changes exhibited in any of the discs, including the disc where there did happen to be a degenerative herniation. And so yes, there is a herniation at C6-7, but that herniation is degenerative.  It's chronic. It predates this accident.  It has nothing to do with this accident.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Doctor, when it comes to herniations, that injury, whether chronic or --
speaker: MR. SPEZIALI

text: It's not an injury.  It's not an injury.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: That condition, whether chronic or traumatic, correct, will that go back to its normal condition afterwards, or herniation, will it remain as is?
speaker: MR. SPEZIALI

text: So that's a good question.  So herniations, a small subset of them will actually continue to change shape.  Most of them get bigger.  Some stay the same.  And a small fraction of them actually will over time get smaller.  And that has nothing, again, to do with whether they are traumatic or degenerative.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Right.  That was my question.
speaker: MR. SPEZIALI

text: That's just period.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Yeah.
speaker: MR. SPEZIALI

text: Yeah.  Herniations -- like any other tissue in the body, herniations can change shape and morphology as time goes on.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: No further questions, Doctor.
speaker: MR. SPEZIALI

text: - - - REDIRECT EXAMINATION
All right.  Dr. Dheer, if someone were asymptomatic and then had a traumatic injury and became symptomatic, would you expect to be able to find something on the diagnostic imaging?
speaker: MR. LAVIN

text: Of course.  So if somebody claims that, you know, they had no pain and now they have pain, there has to be something to account for that at the, you know, the physical level in the physical universe that we live in.  There has to be something to account for that. And certainly we see that.  You know, we see traumatic injuries that have developed in people that account for, you know, a change in symptoms. Absolutely.  But again, if there is no such finding on the MRI, there is nothing to account for a change in symptom.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.  And then similarly, you indicated that someone could have a pre-existing protrusion or bulge and have a new superimposed injury on top of that injury, correct?
speaker: MR. LAVIN

text: Yes, correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did you find that here?
speaker: MR. LAVIN

text: No, no.  Again, there was no traumatic or recent or acute type of change anywhere in the right shoulder or the cervical spine that could be attributed to, you know, the events-in-question here. Everything was, you know, had been there for a very long time.  It was chronic.  It had been there for a long time.  It was degenerative, meaning it was age-related.  It represented, you know, just wear-and-tear of the spine in a progressive fashion over many years.  And there was nothing in addition to that or on top of that.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.  And I want to clarify something, because it was talked about for a while on cross- examination.  Why do you not need to read the reading radiologist's report?
speaker: MR. LAVIN

text: I mean the short answer is that that's what I do, right?  So I mean how valuable would I be as an expert if I needed somebody else's report to tell me what the images showed? I think my value is that I look at a set of images without any external bias or influence.  And I generate an opinion of what those images show.  I guess it keeps me fair, right?  So yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Have any of the plaintiff's attorney's questions caused you to alter or change the opinions that are detailed in your report?
speaker: MR. LAVIN

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.  When you review MRI films, do you do so objectively?
speaker: MR. LAVIN

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: After reviewing plaintiff's film and being cross-examined by plaintiff's counsel, what is your ultimate opinion to a reasonable degree of medical certainty?
speaker: MR. LAVIN

text: That there is no traumatic injuries or traumatic aggravation of any kind in the right shoulder or the cervical spine.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Thank you, Dr. Dheer.
speaker: MR. LAVIN

text: - - - RECROSS-EXAMINATION
And Doctor, you mentioned about your objective, being objective and being fair.  Just to be clear for the jury, you're here at the behest and on behalf of defense counsel's office, correct?
speaker: MR. SPEZIALI

text: That is correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And you are being paid by them for your time and your opinions here today, correct?
speaker: MR. SPEZIALI

text: For my time, not my opinions, regardless of what my opinions may be.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Right.  And the work you did on this case, correct?
speaker: MR. SPEZIALI

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  No further questions.
speaker: MR. SPEZIALI
